column2: test@test.com test                  A protoplanet is a large planetary embryo that originated within a protoplanetary disc and has undergone internal melting to produce a differentiated interior. Protoplanets are thought to form out of kilometer-sized planetesimals that gravitationally perturb each other's orbits and collide
column3: gradually coalescing into the dominant planets. In the case of the Solar System
column4: it is thought that the collisions of planetesimals created a few hundred planetary embryos. Such embryos were similar to Ceres and Pluto with masses of about 1022 to 1023 kg and were a few thousand kilometers in diameter. Over the course of hundreds of millions of years
column5: they collided with one another. The exact sequence whereby planetary embryos collided to assemble the planets is not known
column6: but it is thought that initial collisions would have replaced the first generation of embryos with a second generation consisting of fewer but larger embryos. These in their turn would have collided to create a third generation of fewer but even larger embryos. Eventually
column7: only a handful of embryos were left
column8: which collided to complete the assembly of the planets proper.
